reviews.text: The Lodge is nice, very comfortable and spacious. They have private rooms and dorm style facilities. We took the private room, the room was quite clean and spacious. Had a great view of the sky station from the Room.
reviews.title: Lodge in a footshills of National Park and Absiko Sky station
A real lodge! I loved the breakfast : )
reviews.text: Since this is the only hotel/hostel around, you are not surrounded with many tourists, thus leaving you with nature on all sides.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Breakfast is quite sumptuous, organic and has a good spread. They also have packed lunches in case you want to carry something. There is also a gift store which sells bread, butter, eggs and provisions. There is a fire place where one can sit for some warmth looking at the frozen lake.
reviews.title: upmarket youth hostel

reviews.text: Alternatively you can walk upto the grocery store "Lapporten" in the village which is 2 kms away from the lodge. Directions are pretty simple, walk on E6 - towards Kiruna, as soon as you see a gas station, turn right and on your first left is Lapporten.
reviews.title: Amazing Location

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Kitchen is in the hostel section, and is quite big. The kitchen is divided into two sections so all can cook and sit...has good amount of utensils.
reviews.title: Very expensive but mostly worth it

reviews.text: I stayed here during the low tourist season (october). The main building was closed, but still they left the keys to my room. There is a full kitchen and accommodations.
reviews.title: great place to explore

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The place is ideal for those willing to trek/explore the abisko natural park, as the park entrance is at the hotel's door, and the staff will provide trekking maps. The only downside is that you will have to walk for some 15 minutes to get to the village to buy groceries, but if you came all the way to abisko, you probably won't mind walking a little! Moreover, if you are seeking the northern lights, the more isolated and away from the village's lights, the better!
reviews.title: Nice...

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Like other reviews, the place is functional and clean and we had a great time - ypu come here for the views, nature and the mountains...
reviews.title: the place for winter northern lights

reviews.text: Rooms are spartan (we stayed in the mAin building), and clean. The place offers plenty of common areas...
reviews.title: Spartan but Nice!

reviews.text: Food: Breakfast was nice and the three course dinner is very nice, esoecially considering the price
reviews.title: One of the best Hostels

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The price was well over £200 per night and it definitely felt more like a glorified youth hostel than a hotel, but things are very pricey up in Lapland and you get access to one of the best places in Europe for northern lights watching. We walked to it - 5 mins from the train station (coming from Kiruna) so it was pretty convenient, though there was a big queue at reception when we arrived (a tour group got there just before us). We were annoyed that they asked for an extra £20 as they said a mistake had been made in our bill, even though we showed them an email that said we had fully paid. I didn't bother to argue but it left a bit of a sour taste given how much we'd already paid. They were, though, helpful in arranging a taxi back and answering our questions. The evening meal is included but there was no choice and my partner didn't fancy some of the courses so we went to the hotel's own shop and bought pizzas, which we cooked up in the kitchen (in a separate building). I liked the bar area and the lounge with real fire blazing. I didn't try the sauna or other activities available (eg husky sledding). The room was quite small with 2 single beds (I hate that when you want a double) and a slightly cheap-looking 'wet-room' style shower (ie a curtained off area next to the toilet). It's about 15-20 mins walk to the base of the chairlift up to the sky station - I'm surprised they don't offer free shuttles, at least around the opening time (8pm). It's a great experience going up to the sky station - thankfully they offer warm clothing as we went up through a blizzard. It's a beautiful view from the top even if you don't get to see the lights.
reviews.title: A very expensive but perfectly located "hotel"

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Admittedly the weather is unable to be controlled but unfortunately it was not just the unavailability of trains and sky station that ruined out stay in Abisko. The whole place lacked organisation (particularly tours and activities) and was more a headache than an holiday. Staff didnt seem to be confident as to what was going on when and consequently it was hard to work out any kind of schedule.
reviews.title: Frustrating Experience

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2012, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We had pre-booked a night visit to the sky station but were offered an aurora lounge experience instead as the sky station was closed but what was promised and what was delivered were very different. There were also issues with the resturant (people jumping the que and being able to get away with it-very rude), different information being provided about activities, lack of help to make transport arrangements and terrible wi-if connection. There was also 'no' 'yes' 'no' incident with dog sleding that was totally unprofessional, unnecessary and heart breaking, as well as discrepincy between the quoted price of our stay and what was being asked at check out. The whole place seemed to be run by a bunch of people who took it all a bit to casually. This would be fine if it was a cheap and cheerful place to visit but this is not the case. Many, including my partner and I, had travelled across the globe to visit. We knew it was a turistation and not a hotel (and are happy backpackers 99% of the time) but the whole experience a very expensive waste of time. We were glad to leave.
reviews.title: Fantastic Location for Aurora Sky Station but basic accomodation

reviews.text: My fiance and I stayed here for one night as part of a 3 day trip with Discover the World. The Abisko Turiststation is ideally located to get up to the Aurora Sky Station for viewing the Northern Lights. The accomodation itself is spotlessly clean and comfortable enough for one night. It is not luxury but it is perfectly located in the Abisko national park which is stunning. We had dinner before going up on the chairlift. I enjoyed the dinner (reindeer fillets with potato and lingonberry) but it was not to my fiance's taste!! Following our excursion we enjoyed a few glasses of wine by the open fire in one of the common areas... This was magical and the staff were very accomodating serving us wine until 1am. (the wine is about 7 pounds per glass though!) Breakfast was nice enough, typical swedish with lots of cold meats and cheeses. A hot breakfast was also available. I would recommend this accomodation for the Abisko park and Aurora Sky station but if you are after a luxury break, you would be best off looking elsewhere.
reviews.title: The perfect start to a weeks hiking

reviews.text: Arriving after 26 hours by train from Southenr Sweden it was a pleasure to check in to this famous fjellstation where the Royal Path (Kungsleden) of 450km starts winding its way South. Fine dinner and everything well prepared by StF (Swedish Tourist Organisation). STF had organised a perfec guide (Sara Beckman) who looked well after her 12 person strong group through snow, rain and mainly good but cold weather.
reviews.title: Overpriced, run of the mill, amazing location!

reviews.text: Being perhaps the only option close to the Skystation the STF Turistation does not disappoint. We stayed at the main block (in a double room) but did self-cooking at the kitchen at the hostel end. Unlike what many have said we found the shop on-site quite reasonable, both in terms of pricing and variety of supplies. We brought our food all the way from Stockholm and might have changed our mind if I had known this. Anyway the kitchen was well-equiped and spacious for cooking.
reviews.title: A good base

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Breakfast was plentiful and lovely, room was basic yet spacious, clean and comfortable. Sauna was nice too. Advance booking was not required for lunch and dinner when we were there, but there was only one fixed menu and we did not have it because we did not like fried fish.
reviews.title: Excellent location for the Abisko Sky Station

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2013, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We were there for 2 nights and managed to see a little bit of the aurora on the second night, literally from our room overlooking the lake! If you're staying at the main block do try to ask for a room facing the lake.
reviews.title: Beautiful setting, affordable rooms

reviews.text: The Skystation is around 15 minutes' walk away, perhaps more in the dark. The surrounding area is absolutely beautiful and we did a little walk around without a map and had no problems at all.
reviews.title: Great place for the northern lights

reviews.text: BTW, if you come by train and, like us, arrive after dark, the place is just opposite the train station where the lights are. (There is absolutely no other building with lights around the area you can see. I find the google map slightly misleading as it seems further away on the map.) Go underneath the bridge and there you go.
reviews.title: The perfect place to see the Northern Lights
